title: Replication Workshop
text:
Overview
Goals for today

Align on replication rubric and expectations
Surface and resolve common data and code issues
Ensure everyone leaves with a concrete next-step checklist

Agenda

Replication rubric and deliverables (10 min)
Data access and IDs (CUSIP, GVKEY, PERMNO) walkthrough (20 min)
Code clinic: FE, clustering, winsorizing, SE choices (30 min)
Event-time vs. calendar-time: CAR vs. FMB pitfalls (15 min)
Breakouts and troubleshooting (30–45 min)
Wrap-up and milestones (10 min)

title: Replication Workshop
text:
Replication rubric and expectations

Documentation standards and reproducibility checklist
Required outputs: tables, logs, and data description
Grading criteria and threshold to pass

title: Replication Workshop
text:
Data and identifiers clinic

Access paths to CRSP, Compustat, FF factors
Mapping identifiers and common merge issues
Handling non-matches and many-to-many risks

title: Replication Workshop
text:
Code clinic: modeling and SEs

When to use FE and how to justify them
Clustering choices (firm, time, two-way)
Outliers: winsorize vs. trim and documentation

title: Replication Workshop
text:
Event-time vs calendar-time

CAR (event-time) vs FMB (calendar-time) perspectives
Typical pitfalls and interpretation differences

title: Replication Workshop
text:
Breakouts and troubleshooting

Themed stations: merges, SEs, event windows, FMB setup
TA/peer triage and office hours follow-up

title: Replication Workshop
text:
Milestones and next steps

Individual checklist of remaining tasks
Submission format and due dates

title: Data Analytics in Finance
text:
Welcome to the Data Analytics in Finance course materials. This website contains all the lecture slides, assignments, and resources for the course.


This course is designed to equip students with comprehensive data analysis skills using Stata and a thorough understanding of research methods in finance. The course emphasizes both theoretical foundations and practical implementation of econometric techniques essential for empirical finance research.
Students will learn how to apply statistical analysis techniques with proper understanding of underlying assumptions, interpret data effectively, and address common methodological challenges in financial research. These skills directly support students’ ability to successfully complete their master thesis replication projects and prepare them for data-intensive roles in the financial industry.



By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Data Management: Clean, transform, and merge complex datasets using different identifiers (CUSIP, GVKEY, PERMNO) in Stata
Econometric Theory: Understand and verify the assumptions underlying statistical methods used in finance research
Panel Methods: Implement and interpret fixed effects models with appropriate standard error corrections
Causal Inference: Apply difference-in-differences, event studies, and instrumental variables with proper identification strategies
Research Communication: Create publication-quality tables and essential visualizations for academic papers
Replication Skills: Execute replications of published research with proper documentation and Stata code




The course consists of 6 sessions, each lasting 2 hours 45 minutes. The sessions will be held in person on campus. The course includes individual assignments that reinforce the concepts learned in class.




Data Management and Merging
Data Exploration and Academic Tables
Regression Methods and Identification
Panel Data Methods (with DiD)
Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
Replication Workshop






Regular practice exercises will be posted here throughout the course.







Six assignments throughout the course
All assignments must be completed




TBD




Overall course grade ≥ 55%
Replication exercise grade ≥ 50%
All assignments must be submitted





Students will use:

Stata (version 17 or higher) - All econometric analysis
Access to financial databases through university subscriptions

All software is available through university resources. Basic familiarity with statistics is expected.



Additional resources, recommended readings, and useful links.

title: Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
text:
Overview
Recap of previous lecture

Panel FE and clustering
DiD moved into Panel Methods (parallel trends, staggered adoption pitfalls)

Today’s learning objectives

Compute abnormal returns (AR) and cumulative abnormal returns (CAR)
Distinguish estimation vs. event windows and select a canonical expected-return model
Implement characteristics-based Fama–MacBeth cross-sectional regressions
Report time-series standard errors on risk premia and interpret results

title: Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
text:
Datasets and setup

CRSP daily returns (for CAR)
CRSP monthly returns (for FMB)
Fama–French factors and risk-free rate
Compustat fundamentals and CCM link for firm characteristics

title: Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
text:
Event Studies (CAR)

Define estimation window and event window
Market model vs. FF3/FF5 expected returns (choose one spec in-class)
Compute AR, CAR; cross-sectional tests; visualization of mean CAR with bands

title: Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
text:
Fama–MacBeth (characteristics-based)

Two-pass framework and intuition
Cross-sectional regressions each month: size, B/M, profitability, investment
Time-series SEs on average gammas; limitations and caveats

title: Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
text:
In-class tasks

Task 1: Build CAR around a supplied event list; produce plot and table
Task 2: Run FMB with provided monthly panel; output a publication-quality table

title: Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
